body:
This is a known bug which @calmh was trying to solve but was failing to reproduce.
It seems to be caused by the upgrade from Go 1.3 to Go 1.4.
Can you easily reproduce it?

@AudriusButkevicius yes. In fact i can't get rid of it now, I tried enabling versions on Ubuntu again, it still changes the permissions.

Just changed the revisions settings back on android too, will see if this fixes it, as this is the only thing i changed and thus likely has triggered the bug.
Are you saying that you feel that versioning has caused this?

I believe so, since this problem started appearing after i disabled versioning.

It successfully synced since enabling versioning on android too.
but have not monitored it long enough to say for sure.

Of course it also could've been because of a syncthing update, maybe this more likely.

issue.title: Syncthing destroys all folder and files encrypted with ENCFS

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
## What happened

I am syncing an folder with many subfolders and files that are encrypted with `ENCFS`. I am syncing to the mounted (decrypted) but the unmounted (encrypted) files. This used to work well but since I updated to v0.10.15 as soon as I start syncthing all files and folders within this folder become unreadable.
![korrespondenz org_002](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1161825/5632003/68fba054-95cb-11e4-9ac3-6e0b6049656f.jpg)

It seems that they are not restorable, but permanently lost.
## What did I expect to happen instead of what did happen

Syncthing should sync files independent of there encryption and should never corrupt files 
## What operating system, operating system version and version of Syncthing am I running

I have Syncthing v0.10.15 on Ubuntu 14.04 running on there machine where the incident happened.
## How to reproduce?

Add an ENCFS encrypted folder to Syncthing and start to sync it with an other device

body: In my opinion it has nothing to do with versioning but rather with Syncthing >  v0.10.13. But if one version in your cluster has the bug it will change the permissions on all devices. In my humble opinion you should work on a better release model with a stable and a nightly version.

Yes, cause http://build.syncthing.net is there just for fun.
Show me a piece of software that never had bugs.
And if you read the above comments, it seems that the bug is in the standard library.

Hey AudriusButkevicius, don't get me wrong, this wasn't meant to be an assault. Syncthing is a great peace of software and I appreciate the great work of all contributors. The only thing that I wanted to suggest is:
If you care about users who use Syncthing, you should consider stability as one of the most important things. This bug concerns data integrity and is a major bug. I had to shutdown Syncthing on all my computers due to this bug, and can't use it anymore until the bug gets fixed. 
From a user perspective I don't care, where the bug comes from. Or who is to blame, as it's not about blaming someone. 
But a release model where you not push any minor change that was not tested in the wild, to the end users, would be helpful.

We do have tests, and we do run the software ourselves, but this seems to be some edge case which the integration tests exposed after the release.
It seems quite hard to reproduce, hence it's hard to fix (any input would be useful).

We're not at v1.0 yet, which for me does not indicate stable, hence :hankey: happens as we are all testers to some extent.
Regardless, the bug is not as dramatic as you are saying, but given you are a clever man with sensitive data, you can always stay a few releases behind to play it safe and follow the issue tracker to see if there is anything major happening.
You did choose to be on the bleeding edge (and as you say, be part of the people testing in the wild), hence face the music.

Life is hard, and then we all die.
I had the same issue with  v0.10.18.
Same as in the first report above, on the machine running .18? I can't reproduce it with a test any more with the fix as above...

Perhaps you have a mixed cluster of .17 and .18, .17 causes the issue and that propagates to .18.
Hence my autoupgrade PR becomes useful.

@gunwald Give this build a try, on the affected computer (or all of them), after fixing the chmod on the folder root: http://build.syncthing.net/job/syncthing-branch/1568/

If it is what I suspect, you should see one or more messages along the lines of "Dropping invalid nil filename ..." and the problem not occurring again. If it doesn't, and you don't see that, then it's something even weirder. :)

issue.title: 7:59:13: mkdir permission denied

labels.name: bug
labels.description: A problem with current functionality, as opposed to missing functionality (enhancement)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
This worked flawlessly on two of the three computers i'm setting it up on (all osx), but I'm getting a permissions error on one of them -

7:59:13: Stopping folder "iTunes" - mkdir /Volumes/Macintosh\ HD/Music: permission denied

The weird thing is the iTunes folder was already made.  I tried removing the folder and letting snycthing make it to no avail, and I tried settings permissions to drwxrwxrwx all the way up the chain.

Any idea what could be causing this?

Thanks!

issue.title: Tries to overwrite folder root

labels.name: bug
labels.description: A problem with current functionality, as opposed to missing functionality (enhancement)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
```
Jan 13 09:14:23 acro-syncer syncthing: [SFPK3] WARNING: puller: final: rename /data/Lightroom/.syncthing.. /data/Lightroom: directory not
 empty
```

/data/Lightroom is my folder root. This should not happen.
